questions.text: Who discovered X-rays?
questions.solution:
Xrays were discovered by Wilhem roentgen and he is known as the father of radiology for his discovery of xrays. The first image he xrayed was a hand of his wife.

Reference: Yochum and Rowe’s essentials of skeletal radiology, third edition, volume 1 page xxvii

questions.text: Short TE and Short TR leads to production of which images on MRI?
questions.solution:
Short TE and TR- T1 Weighted Images

Long TE and TR- T2 Weighted Images

Long TE and short TR- PD Images

Reference: MRI made easy page 13

choices.text: Eating a heavy meal before scan

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for using contrast agent in CT?
questions.solution:
All of the above are contraindications for using contrast agents in CT except metallic implants. Contrast agents are renotoxic hence they are avoided in renal failure patients as it may damage the kidneys. A history of allergy is also a contraindication as it’s use may lead to anaphylactic reaction. Eating a heavy meal predisposes the patient to aspiration if he experiences a reaction to the contrast agent.

Metallic implants are not a contraindication for CT. However it increases the artefacts in CT images.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 84

questions.text: Piezoelectric crystals are used in?
questions.solution:
Piezoelectric crystals have a property of expansion and contraction when a voltage is applied to the crystals and produces sound waves. This property is used in USG to generate the ultrasound waves.

Reference: Farrs Physics for medial imaging page 148

questions.text: For increasing the penetration of xrays, what should be increased?
questions.solution:
Quantity of Xrays is determined by current. Higher current produces more electrons thus increasing the quantity of Xrays.

Quality of Xrays is controlled by voltage difference. Higher voltage difference increases the speed of electrons thus increasing the penetrating power of Xrays and in-turn the quality of Xrays.

Reference : Christensen’s Physics of diagnostic radiology page 33-34

questions.text: A patient presented to EMD with sudden onset of breathlessness. He underwent a CXR which showed pneumothorax. After that he underwent an ICD placement. Following ICD placement the following x ray is obtained after 4 days. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
In patients with pneumothorax the treatment of choice is insertion of ICD tube. In The patient mentioned above, he underwent a ICD insertion for pneumothorax. In patients with pneumothorax after placement of ICD tube, there should be resolution of pneumothorax. If this does not happen even after some time a suspicion of bronchopleural fistula should be kept in mind.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2525

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented to OPD with complaints of breathlessness on exertion. He underwent a CXR which showed in the following image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows hyperinflation of lung fields, flattening of the diaphragm and narrow mediastinum. These findings along with a history of smoking leads to a diagnosis of emphysema-COPD.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2487

questions.text: A patient presented with cough for long duration and significant weight loss. He underwent a HRCT which is shown below. Identify the most probable diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple nodular infiltrates distributed in the lung parenchyma which gives a tree in bud appearance. This is usually seen in endobronchial spread of disease. The presence of cavity in the contralateral lung and infiltrates in the lung would point to a diagnosis of TB.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1014

questions.text: A person working in ceramic industry presented with a shortness of breath on exertion. He underwent a HRCT chest which is shown below. What is the feature shown which helps in the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The given image shows a calcified lymphnodes. THe patient works in ceramic factory. This all points to a diagnosis of silicosis. Other findings seen in silicosis is pulmonary nodules and eggshell calcification of lymphnodes.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2377

questions.text: A patient working in shipping industries presented with difficulty in breathing and weight loss, He underwent a sputum examination which showed mesothelial cells. Which of the following HRCT findings corresponds to the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows pleural thickening and calcification along the pleura. The person is working in shipping industry where he has an exposure to asbestos. This all findings point to a diagnosis of asbestosis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2372

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with acute onset of abdominal pain and vomiting. He underwent an AXR which is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above given xray shows multiple air fluid levels in step ladder fashion. This findings point to diagnosis of intestinal obstruction. In the above image a concertina like appearance is seen, this points to a diagnosis of jejunal bowle loops. Ileal loops will be featureless and large bowel loops will show presence of haustrations.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2081

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Given image shows a radioopaque substance in the abdomen. Among the options given above the option that matches with the description is a foreign body.

Reference: Foreign Bodies Tim B. Hunter and Mihra S. Taljanovic RadioGraphics 2003 23:3, 731-757

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows extensive fat stranding around the pancreas and minimal free fluid is peripancreatic region. This helps to localize the pathology around the pancreas. Thus help in diagnosis of pancreatitis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2013

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis on the basis of given image?
questions.solution:
Given image shows a filling defect within the stomach which is arising from the wall of stomach. This fings lead to a diagnosis of stomach carcinoma. In contrast to a gastric ulce which shows a punched out lesion.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1699

questions.text: Which of the following hepatic lesion shows early arterial filling, progresesive centripetal filling and delayed washout on CECT scan?
questions.solution:
Hemagiomas usually are congenital lesions. They have a rich arterial supply hence show an elary filling and delayed washout. This characteristic help in identifying hemangioma from other lesions.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2752

questions.text: What is the diagnosis on the basis of the given below image?
questions.solution:
The given above image shows a barium enema. In the image there is loss of haustration of the colon giving to a lead pipe appearance. This finding is characteristic of ulcerative colitis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1159

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given image is a barium enema image showing a filling defect in the descending colon giving an apple core appearance and narrowing of the lumen. This findings are supportive int he diagnosis of carcinoma colon.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1754

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a superior mesentric artery which is very near to the descending aorta. The angle between the SMA and descending aorta is <15. This gives rise to SMA syndrome. THis occurs in lean and thin individual or in patients with sudden loss of weight.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2089

questions.text: A cystic lesion in the peripancreatic region following a few attacks of acute pancreatitis is known as?
questions.solution:
In a patient of pancreatitis folowing recurrent attacks of pancreatitis there is development of pseudocyst or walled off necrosis. After an attackof acute pancreatitis leads to pseudocyst formation. In patients with chronic pancreatitis it leads to formation of walled off necrosis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2015

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with acute onset of right sided flank pain radiating to groin and hematuria. Find the xray among the following which matches the patient's diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given symptoms point to a diagnosis of ureteric calculi as the pain is of radiating nature which is usually seen in uretric calculus blocking the flow of urine. Among the given images the image which is shows ureteric calculus is c.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 200

questions.text: Delayed striatogram is seen in?
questions.solution:
Pyelonephritis is the inflammation of kidneys. In such condition on CT IVP striated appearance is noted which increases the tubule transit time of contrast and delayed perfusion of tubules by contrast which will ultimately lead to appearance of striated nephrogram.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 16

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis from the below image.
questions.solution:
Given below is a CT reformatted image of the kidneys. It shows the lower poles of the kidneys is fused with each other and the have not ascended upto their normal levels. This findings p[oint to a diagnosis of horseshoe kidneys.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 48

questions.text: A patient presented to emergency department with a history of RTA. He underwent an CECT abdomen which shows the following. Identify the most probable diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a focal non-enhancing area in the renal parenchyma. Though infarct does look like same it has a wedge shape and in presence of history of trauma, contusion would be a better option than an infarct.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 457

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis from the given below image?
questions.solution:
Given image is an USG image of the kidneys. It shows that there is dilation of the pelvicalyceal system which is shows by hypoechoic central portaion. There is also a hyperechoic focus in the ureter distal to the dialted pelvicalyceal system. It also shows posterior acoustic shadow. This findings point towards a calculus. Thus the image shows in of ureteric calculus with backpressure changes in the form of dilation of PC system.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 53

questions.text: What type of haemorrhage is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Given image shows a CT image of brain. It shows a biconvex hyperdense collection. This is suggestive of haemorrhage.

Reference : Osborn Brain edition 2 page 21

questions.text: What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
Given is an CT image of the brain. It shows a hyperdense structure in the brain parenchyma in the region of the middle cerebral artery. This is known as hyperdense MCA sign. It is an early predictor of stroke. As changes of stroke are not seen upto 6 hours on CT scan but this sign is noted very early. The presence of hypredense vessels suggest a thrombosis in the vessels.

Reference : Osborn Brain edition 2 page 212

questions.text: Identify the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Given image is an MRI image of the brain which shows enlarged posterior cranial fossa (filled by CSF ) and small cerebellum. The CSF appears hyperintense on T2WI which is shows above.

Reference : Osborn Brain edition 2 page 1186

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Given image is of CT angiography showing an enhancing group of vessels. This is known as nidus of vessels. This is a particular about arteriovenous malformation.

Reference : Osborn Brain edition 2 page 157

questions.text: What is the procedure done in radiological investigations to reduce the motion artefact generated by the movement of the heart?
questions.solution:
To reduce the motion artefacts in certain radiological procedures like coronary angiography and cardiac MRI, we do ECG gating in which the signals are used which occurs in diastole phase of cardiac cycle. In this process the signal acquisition is correlated with ECG cycle.

Reference: MRI made easy page 172

questions.text: 'Snowman shaped heart' is seen in?
questions.solution:
In TAPVC, there is aberrant connection of pulmonary veins with right atrium. This gives a snowman shaped heart on CXR due to draining veins into the right atrium.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2637

questions.text: Identify the investigation being done
questions.solution:
The above investigation shown is an MRI of heart. In this image soft tissues are very well appreciated. The fluid in the stomach and fat is seen as hyperintense structure. This helps in identifying the image as MRI of heart(cardiac MRI).

Reference: MRI made easy page 172

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given is a CT contrast image of the thorax in which there is contrast noted in the chambers of heart. There is a hypointense filling defect as shown by the arrow. This is suggestive of LV clot. This occurs commonly after myocardial infarction

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2599

questions.text: Patient presented in opd with complaints of bilateral wrist pain, more severe in morning and low grade fever since 2 years. What is probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given image shows a hand xray showing involvement of metacarpophalangeal joints, proximal interphalangeal joints and wrist with relative sparing of distal interphalangeal joints. There is also subchondral cyst formation, reactive sclerosis and subarticular osteopenia. This all findings help in diagnosis this as a case of rheumatoid arthritis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 3039

questions.text: Identify the type of fracture shown in the given xray
questions.solution:
Given image shows a fractuer of distal end of radius. There is volar displacement of the distal end of radius. This all features help in diagnosis as colle’s fracture. This usually occurs in old aged females who fall on outstretched hands.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 3149

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false.
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion: STIR images are used for visualisation of pathology.
Reason: Edema is well appreciated on STIR images.
questions.solution:
STIR is a fat suppression sequence in which the signal from Fat is suppressed. In pathological tissues like there is increased water content. On suppressing the fat, the edema is well visualised, thus pathology can be easily identified.

Reference: MRI made easy page 115

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion: A pregnant patient should not undergo a CT scan.
Reason: It causes congenital anomalies.
questions.solution:
CT scan uses xray for production of images. Xrays are ionizing radiations. They have ap potential to induce various caongenital anomalies in the fetus thus a pregnant woman should not uindergo a CT scan.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2802

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion: HRCT is better than CXR for interstitial lung disease.
Reason: HRCT shows detailed structure of the lungs.
questions.solution:
The chest radiograph has its limitations. It is normal in 10 to 15 percent of symptomatic patients with proven infiltrative lung disease, in up to 30 percent of those with bronchiectasis, and in close to 60 percent of patients with emphysema. In several studies, the chest radiograph has been shown to have an overall sensitivity of 80 percent and a specificity of 82 percent for detection of diffuse lung disease. Chest radiography could provide a confident diagnosis in only 23 percent of cases, and those confident diagnoses proved correct only in 77 percent of cases. For these reasons, high resolution computed tomography (HRCT, also called thin-section CT scanning), is frequently used to help clarify specific problems. Typical features of the lung parenchyma and of the small airways correlate with obstructive or restrictive pulmonary function tests

Reference: High resolution computed tomography of the lungs. https://www.uptodate.com/contents/high-resolution-computed-tomography-of-the-lungs/print

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion: Horseshoe kidney on imaging studies appear at a lower level than the normal position of the kidneys.
Reason: Their ascent is blocked by the renal arteries.
questions.solution:
In horseshoe kidneys, the lower poles are fused together. During normal development the renal buds arise in the pelvis and migrate upwards. But in horseshoe kidneys as their lower poles are fused, there ascent is stooped by inferior mesentric artery.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 58

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion: Right lower lobe pneumonia obscures the right heart border.
Reason: Right lower lobe lies in vicinity of the right heart border hence silhouettes the right heart border.
questions.solution:
Right lower lobe pneumonia lies near the diaphragm. In right lower lobe pneumonia there is silhoutting of the right dome opf diaphragm. Right middle lobe lies near the right heart b order and right middle lobe pneumonia leads to silhoutting of the right heart border.

Reference: Thoracic imaging-Pulmonary and cardiovascular radiology edition 3 page 402

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
The given images shows the xray appearance of various cardiovascular malformation and their xray appearance.

Egg on side appearance is seen in ebsteins anomaly shown by option c. It occurs due to tricuspid atresion.

Snowman heart is seen in TAPVC. OT occurs due to pulmonary veins draining into the right atrium and causing it’s enlargement

Boot shaped heart is seen in tetrology of fallot and occurs because of RV hypertrophy

Reverse 3 sign is seen in coarctation of aorta.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2660

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
The given questions asks about the modalities and their principles.

In MRI, the magnetic resonance of the tissues is used to generate the signals.

The USG uses the sound waves for generation of it’s image. This is known as harmonic imaging

CT scans uses Xrays and the property of various tissues to absorb different amount of xrays and reflect it thus producing the image.

Reference: Farrs Physics for medial imaging page 103, 147, 169

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Brain infarction: In brain infarct there is edema and blurring of grey white matter differentiation seen as hypodensity in involved region

Parenchymal haemorrhage: Blood is hyperdense on CT scan. In brain haemorrhage there is bleeding in the brain which is seen as hyperdense area in the brain

EDH: EDH is a biconvex collection of blood between the dura and inner table of brain.

SDH: In SDH there is collection of brain blood beneath the dura between the dura and arachnoid layer of the brain.

Reference : Osborn Brain edition 2 page 21, 118, 212

questions.text: Match the following (type of modality)
questions.solution:
The given images shows various modalites and their images as seen on DICOM images.

Reference: Farrs Physics for medial imaging page 103, 147, 169

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
This are protocols designed for use in emergency to identify major trauma and triage the patient for further assessment.

FAST- Focused assessment with sonography in trauma

BLUE- Bedside lung ultrasound in emergency

POCUS- Point of care ultrasound

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2095

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a chest xray. The pointed arrow represents a pulmonary bay where the pulmonary artery originating form the heat produce a shadow and a slight bulge. This is characteristic of pulmonary artery origin.

Reference : Felson's principles of chest roentgenology edition 4 page 40

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a CT scan of the abdomen. In this section we can see liver, pancreas, gallbladder, kidneys and vessels. THe points structure shows here is tail of pancreas.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 441

questions.text: In the image given below, identify the structure which has only white matter fibres.
questions.solution:
Given is an MRI image of the brain. THe following structures are pointed:

  1. Caudate nucleus
  2. Globus pallidus
  3. Corpus callosum(splenium part)
  4. Thalamus.

The only structure which has white matter is corpus callosum among the above.

Reference : Diagnostic and Surgical Imaging Anatomy(Brain, Head & Neck, Spine) page 67

questions.text: identify the marked structure
questions.solution:
Given image is an Xray of the foot showing tarsal bones. The structure pointed is navicular bone.


Reference: Yochum and Rowe’s essentials of skeletal radiology, third edition, volume 1 page 119

questions.text: identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
Given image is of CT brain.The pointes structure represents a sulcus. The sulcus in the brain at that region is lateral/ sylvina sulcus.

Reference : Diagnostic and Surgical Imaging Anatomy(Brain, Head & Neck, Spine) page 67

questions.text: Identify the procedure being done here.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a radiopaque material within the upper GI tract. In barium swallow we visualise the upper GIT which includes oesophagus and upper stomach. In barium meal we visualise the stomach and mid part of the GIT. IN barium enema the contrast is given through rectum and the distal colon is visualised. Thus the method shown in the above image is barium swallow.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI’s Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1685
